report_title: Nonferrous Metal Recycling in the US
executive_summary: The Nonferrous Metal Recycling industry revenue has faltered due to poor operating conditions and weakening demand from several key markets. However, industry revenue is primarily a function of nonferrous metal prices, which experienced significant volatility over the past five years due to the cyclical nature of metal prices on world markets. So, industry-wide revenue has decreased at a CAGR of 0.2% to $23.3 billion over the five years to 2023, including an estimated 6.8% decrease in 2023 alone, when profit is projected to decrease to 4.3%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Fluctuating metal prices and conditions in key sectors have challenged the industry, but nonferrous metal recyclers have emerged victorious. COVID-19 and the temporary closure of downstream establishments initially pushed metal prices down, constraining industry revenue in 2020. However, the price of metals, especially aluminum, surged as restrictions were loosened in 2021. Nonferrous metal recycling revenue surged 43.7% as a result in 2021 alone. While metal prices have since tempered, recyclers have been beneficiaries as key markets have looked to save money by turning to less expensive alternatives to virgin products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Nonferrous Metal Recyclers Have Barriers to Overcome
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Recyclers have had to contend with external competition from manufacturers of primary nonferrous metals (IBISWorld report 33141), which have presented a significant source of external competition for the industry's copper segment, in particular. Manufacturers are exiting the market because of underperformance, leading to a drop in the number of manufacturers and increased consolidation. Companies are consolidating operations and implementing restructuring strategies to navigate difficult conditions.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Growth of Eco-Friendly Products Benefits Recycled Metals
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Greater demand for eco-friendly products and materials has led to steady growth for nonferrous metal recycling despite fluctuations in commodity prices. Recycling nonferrous metals reduces energy consumption significantly compared to extracting and refining metals from mined ores. Nonferrous metal recyclers have also benefited from economic incentives offered by some states, like tax credits or grants, to businesses involved in sustainable practices like recycling. These incentives have supported scrap metal recycling facilities.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Infrastructure Act Spurs Capital Investment in Nonferrous Metal Recycling
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act represents a $1.2 trillion investment, with $550 billion above the baseline. By mid-2024, more than $454 billion from the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law will have been allocated to enhance critical sectors, including recycling. The Battery Recycling Best Practices and the Rare Earth Elements Demonstration Facility have the most impact, with allocations of $10 million and $140 million, respectively. These initiatives have driven higher capital investments in nonferrous metal recycling, emphasizing efficient recycling practices and advanced technologies. Enhanced funding supports sustainable waste management and resource recovery, benefiting the recycling sector.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The industry will benefit from increased industrial production
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rising disposable incomes will boost the global consumption of goods that require nonferrous metal inputs, such as cars, airplanes, machines, computers and electronic products. As the middle class expands in emerging markets, consumption of commodities will continue to hike rapidly, putting pressure on the world's natural resources.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Nonferrous metal price hikes will benefit the industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Nonferrous metal recycling rates will continue to rise. This will increase the supply of cost-competitive and energy-efficient inputs for manufacturers, making recyclers a reliable alternative to virgin producers for long-term contracts. Rising nonferrous metal prices will enable manufacturers to receive higher selling prices for reprocessed products than what they paid for scrap inputs.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Environmental trends will encourage manufacturers to use sustainable materials and reduce carbon emissions
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Automakers and aerospace manufacturers will increasingly use recycled aluminum and other light nonferrous metal alloys, such as specialty-grade steel, instead of regular carbon steel in response to environmental regulations and consumer preferences. High oil prices have also motivated automobile and aerospace manufacturers to use aluminum instead of steel to reduce the weight of motor vehicles and airplanes, thereby boosting fuel efficiency.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Government investments will result in higher capital for recycling nonferrous metals
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The $1.2 trillion Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) – also known as the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law – is aimed at upgrading national infrastructure and includes $550.0 billion above the baseline investment. Nearly $746.0 billion in IIJA funding is yet to be announced as of June 2024, suggesting ongoing growth opportunities for industries like Nonferrous Metal Recycling.

industry_definition: This industry recovers copper, aluminum, lead and other nonferrous metals from scrap and then manufactures primary forms (e.g. bar, billet, bloom, cake, ingot, slab, slug and wire) from the recovered metals through secondary smelting and refining processes.
key_trends: The Nonferrous Metal Recycling industry competes based on product price, quality, reliability and turnaround time. Companies also strive to maintain competitive advantages with quality products and low-cost manufacturing.
The industry competes with nonferrous metal mining and foreign nonferrous metal recycling facilities, which produce many of the same products as the industry.

Increasingly unfavorable operating conditions have led to significant consolidation throughout the Nonferrous Metal Recycling industry, increasingly shuttering underperforming facilities, reducing headcount and engaging in other restructuring activities to boost profit.
The Nonferrous Metal Recycling industry will benefit from increased industrial production and environmental trends, encouraging manufacturers to use sustainable materials and reduce carbon emissions.
Commercial Metals Co. generates a significant share of its nonferrous brokerage revenue from export sales. The company benefits from its convenient location in both North America and Europe.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Recycled aluminum finds application in motors, generators, lighting fixtures and other electrical equipment. Recycled zinc and other nonferrous metals offer versatile uses in various electrical equipment.
The transportation industry widely uses recycled aluminum in engine blocks, wheels and powertrains.
Industrial manufacturing markets, namely machinery and fabricated metal product (e.g. nonferrous castings) manufacturers, also consume a significant portion of recycled nonferrous metals.
The construction industry uses recycled nonferrous metals in new residential builds and infrastructure, such as bridges and tunnels.
This segment includes jewelry, the production of coins and other falling reliance on nonferrous metals.
